column1: /// @notice If you have found a bug, please contact andrew@realitycards.io- no hack pls!!
contract RCTreasury is Ownable, NativeMetaTransaction, IRCTreasury {
/// @dev orderbook instance, to remove users bids on foreclosure
/// @dev nfthub instance, to query current card owner
/// @dev address of (as yet non existent) Bridge for withdrawals to mainnet
/// @dev address of the Factory so only the Factory can add new markets
/// @dev so only markets can use certain functions
/// @dev the rental payments made in each market
/// @dev rent taken and allocated to a particular market
/// @dev a quick check if a uesr is foreclosed
/// @dev to keep track of the size of the rounding issue between rent collections
/// @param deposit the users current deposit in wei
/// @param rentalRate the daily cost of the cards the user current owns
/// @param bidRate the sum total of all placed bids
/// @param lastRentCalc The timestamp of the users last rent calculation
/// @param lastRentalTime The timestamp the user last made a rental
/// @dev only parameters that need to be are here, the rest are in the Factory
/// @dev minimum rental duration (1 day divisor: i.e. 24 = 1 hour, 48 = 30 mins)
/// @dev max deposit balance, to minimise funds at risk
/// @dev whitelist to only allow certain addresses to deposit
/// @dev if true, cannot deposit, withdraw or rent any cards across all events
/// @dev if true, cannot rent any cards for specific market
/// @dev high level owner who can change the factory address
event LogUserForeclosed(address indexed user, bool indexed foreclosed)
// at initiation, uberOwner and owner will be the same

column2: // MinRental is a divisor of 1 day(86400 seconds), 24*6 will set to 10 minutes

column1: /// @notice check that funds haven't gone missing during this function call
// using >= not == in case anyone sends tokens direct to contract
/// @notice only allow markets to call these functions
/// @notice only allow orderbook to call these functions
/// @dev so only markets can move funds from deposits to marketPots and vice versa
// min rental event emitted by market. Nothing else need be emitted.
/// @notice minimum rental duration (1 day divisor: i.e. 24 = 1 hour, 48 = 30 mins)
/// @notice set max deposit balance, to minimise funds at risk
/// @param _newBalanceLimit the max balance to set in wei
/// @notice if true, cannot deposit, withdraw or rent any cards
/// @notice if true, cannot make a new rental for a specific market
/// @notice if true, users must be on the whitelist to deposit
/// @notice Add a user to the whitelist
/// @notice Add multiple users to the whitelist
/// @dev deploying and setting a new factory is effectively an upgrade
/// @dev this is seperated so owner so can be set to multisig, or burn address to relinquish upgrade ability
/// @dev ... while maintaining governance over other governanace functions
/// @dev it is passed the user instead of using msg.sender because might be called
/// @param _user the user to credit the deposit to
/// @param _amount the amount to deposit, must be approved
""User not approved to send this amount""
// do some cleaning up, it might help cancel their foreclosure
// this deposit could cancel the users foreclosure
/// @notice withdraw a users deposit either directly or over the bridge to the mainnet
/// @dev this is the only function where funds leave the contract
/// @param _localWithdrawal if true then withdraw to the users address, otherwise to the bridge
// only allow withdraw if they have no bids,
// OR they've had their cards for at least the minimum rental period
// stpe 1: collect rent on owned cards
// step 3: remove bids if insufficient deposit
/// @dev not strictly required but prevents markets being shortchanged due to rounding issues
// only markets can call these functions
/// @notice a rental payment is equivalent to moving from user's deposit to market pot,
/// @param _amount amount of rent to pay in wei
/// @notice a payout is equivalent to moving from market pot to user's deposit (the opposite of payRent)
/// @dev called by _collectRentAction() in the market in situations where collectRentUser() collected too much rent
/// @notice ability to add liqudity to the pot without being able to win (called by market sponsor function).
/// @notice tracks when the user last rented- so they cannot rent and immediately withdraw,
/// @notice provides the sum total of a users bids accross all markets (whether active or not)
/// @notice updates users rental rates when ownership changes
/// @dev rentalRate = sum of all active bids
/// @param _oldOwner the address of the user losing ownership
/// @param _newOwner the address of the user gaining ownership
/// @param _oldPrice the price the old owner was paying
/// @param _newPrice the price the new owner will be paying
// The new owners rent must be collected before adjusting their rentalRate
// See if the new owner has had a rent collection before or after this ownership change
// the new owner has a more recent rent collection
// they have enough funds, just collect the extra
// the new owner has an old rent collection, do they own anything else?
// rent collect upto ownership change time
// first card owned, set start time
// Must add before subtract, to avoid underflow in the case a user is only updating their price.
/// @dev increase bidRate when new bid entered
/// @dev called when all a user's bids have been removed, disables foreclosure state
/// @notice returns the rent due between the users last rent calcualtion and
/// @notice ..the current block.timestamp for all cards a user owns
/// @notice calcualtes the rent owed between the given timestamps
/// @param _price the rental rate for this time period
/// @param _rent the rent due for this time period
/// @dev the timestamps can be given in any order
/// @notice returns the amount of deposit a user is able to withdraw
/// @notice ..after considering rent due to be paid
/// @notice returns the current estimate of the users foreclosure time
/// @param _newBid calculate foreclosure including a new card
/// @param _timeOfNewBid timestamp of when a new card was gained
// calculate how long they can own the new card for
// if no rentals they'll foreclose after the heat death of the universe
/// @notice call for a rent collection on the given user
/// @notice IF the user doesn't have enough deposit, returns foreclosure time
/// @param _timeToCollectTo the timestamp to collect rent upto
/// @return newTimeLastCollectedOnForeclosure the time the user foreclosed if they foreclosed in this calculation
// The User has run out of deposit already.
Users last collection time = previousCollectionTime + timeTheirDepsitLasted
// User has enough deposit to pay rent.
/// moving from the user deposit to the markets availiable balance
}",7143.0,761.0,"[H-01] Unchecked ERC20 transfers can cause lock up

Some major tokens went live before ERC20 was finalized, resulting in a discrepancy whether the transfer functions should (A) return a boolean or (B) revert/fail on error. The current best practice is that they should revert, but return “true” on success. However, not every token claiming ERC20-compatibility is doing this — some only return true/false
column2: some revert, but do not return anything on success. This is a well known issue, heavily discussed since mid-2018.

column1: This modifier is present on most functions, but is missing on topupMarketBalance:

In the case where an ERC20 token which is not reverting on failures is used, a malicious actor could call `topupMarketBalance` with a failing transfer, but also move the value of `marketBalance` above the actual holdings. After this, deposit, withdrawDeposit, payRent, payout, sponsor, etc. could be locked up and always failing with “Books are unbalanced”.

Anyone can call `topupMarketBalance` with some unrealistically large number, so that marketBalance does not overflow, but is above the actually helping balances. This is only possible if the underlying ERC20 used is not reverting on failures, but is returning “false” instead.   [H-04] Anyone can affect deposits of any user and turn the owner of the token

On RCTreasury, we have the method `collectRentUser`. This method is public, so anyone can call it using whatever user and whatever timestamp. So, calling this method using user = XXXXX and _timeToCollectTo = type(uint256).max), would make isForeclosed[user] = true.
The function `payout` of RCTreasury.sol doesn't undo the isForeclosed state of a user. This would be possible because with a payout a user will receive funds so he can lose his isForeclosed status.
[M-02] Critical uberOwner address changes should be a two-step process

As specified, `uberOwners` of Factory, Orderbook and Treasury have the highest privileges in the system because they can upgrade contracts of market, Nfthub, order book, treasury, token and factory which form the critical components of the protocol.

The contracts allow for `uberOwners` to be changed to a different address from the contract owner/deployer using the changeUberOwner() function which is callable by the current uberOwner. While this function checks for zero-address, there is no validation of the new address being correct. If the current uberOwner incorrectly uses an invalid address for which they do not have the private key, then the system gets locked because the uberOwner cannot be corrected and none of the other functions that require uberOwner caller can be executed.
[M-03] Missing balancedBooks modifier could result in failed system insolvency detection

The `balancedBooks` modifier is used to “check that funds haven't gone missing during this function call” and is applied to deposit, withdrawDeposit, payRent, payout and sponsor Treasury functions which move funds in and out of the Treasury or adjust its market/user balances.

However, this modifier is missing in the `refundUser()` and topupMarketBalance() functions which also perform similar actions. The impact is that any miscalculations in these functions will lead to the system becoming insolvent.
[M-16] Deposits can be denied by abusing maxContractBalance

A whale can stop anyone from depositing by front-running a user's deposit with a deposit that pushes the contract balance to the maxContractBalance limit first. The user's deposit will then fail in the check. Afterwards, the whale can withdraw again.

Any users can be blocked from depositing which prevents them from renting cards. This allows an attacker to manipulate the outcome of a market in their favor by strategically preventing other competitors to bid on their cards (causing forfeiture due to a low deposit balance).   [M-17] Function `foreclosureTimeUser` returns a shorter user's foreclosure time than expected

The function `foreclosureTimeUser` of `RCTreasury` underestimates the user's foreclosure time if the current time is not the user's last rent calculation time. The underestimation of the foreclosure time could cause wrong results when determining the new owner of the card.

The variable `timeLeftOfDeposit` at line 668 is calculated based on `depositAbleToWithdraw(_user)`, the user's deposit minus the rent from the last rent calculation to the current time. Thus, the variable timeLeftOfDeposit indicates the time left of deposit, starting from now. However, at line 672, the foreclosureTimeWithoutNewCard is calculated by timeLeftOfDeposit plus the user's last rent calculation time instead of the current time. As a result, the user's foreclosure time is reduced. From another perspective, the rent between the last rent calculation time and the current time is counted twice.",8.0,"pragma solidity 0.8.4
contract RCTreasury is Ownable, NativeMetaTransaction, IRCTreasury {
event LogUserForeclosed(address indexed user, bool indexed foreclosed)
""User not approved to send this amount""
}",4101.0,2,5,"Okay, I'm trying to figure out the vulnerabilities in this smart contract. Let me go through each function step by step and see what could potentially go wrong.

Starting with the constructor. It initializes the EIP712, sets the minimum rental divisor, max contract balance, token address, and enables the whitelist. I don't see anything immediately wrong here, but I should keep an eye on the dependencies like EIP712 and the token setup.
Looking at the modifiers, balancedBooks checks the contract's balance. Make sure this isn't easily bypassable. The onlyMarkets and onlyOrderbook modifiers seem okay, requiring specific roles.

Now, the deposit function. It transfers funds from the user to the contract, updates the user's deposit, and checks if it's foreclosed. vulnerabilities here might include overrides or not properly handling the transfer, but it uses SafeCast, which is good. Also, it checks if the new deposit exceeds the rental limit. Not sure about this yet.

The withdrawDeposit function allows users to take out money. It checks if it's foreclosed, uses block timestamps, and interacts with the orderbook. The use of block.timestamp could lead to timing attacks if not carefully handled. Also, the $amount is coming from the user's deposit, which is tracked, so that seems safe.
TopupMarketBalance seems straightforward, just adding to the market balance. It might not have any issues unless the market balance isn't properly tracked, but the variable exists, so probably not.
CheckSponsorship is a view function, which is good for not consuming gas unnecessarily. It checks if the sender has enough allowance and balance. No overt issues here.

PayRent is an external function that deducts from the market balance. It correctly checks if there's enough balance before proceeding. Maybe the issue would be if the market balance isn't updated correctly after certain transactions, but I don't see it here.

Payout and Refund functions handle distributing funds and refunds. They correctly adjust the market pot and user deposits. The Refund function also resets the user's status if foreclosed. The main thing is the checks for global pause and market permissions, which seem handled.
Sponsor function adds to the market pot and tracks total market pots. It should be secure since it's in the contract's control.
UpdateLastRentalTime simply sets the last rental time. AView function is fine.
UserTotalBids and userDeposit are just view functions, so no issues unless they're used incorrectly elsewhere.

UpdateRentalRate is more complex. Changes based on ownership transfer. It checks times and updates rates. Not sure about potential overflow issues with uint128 casts. Also, state changes might affect multiple users if not handled correctly.
Increase and DecreaseBidRate are straightforward. They modify the user's bid rate. No problems unless the orderbook isn't properly updated, but that's handled in withdrawDeposit.
ResetUser sets isForeclosed to false. This could be a point of vulnerability if not properly checked elsewhere, but the function does have a balancedBooks modifier, so that's good.

RentOwedUser and RentOwedBetweenTimestmaps are helper functions for calculating owed rent. These use uint256 for calculations, which could cause overflows or issues with precision. It's using 1 days as a divisor, which is a fixed conversion.
DepositAbleToWithdraw calculates how much can be withdrawn. It subtracts owed rent from the deposit. Potential issues with integer overflows, but since it's using uint256, it's a risk.

ForeclosureTimeUser is a view function that calculates the time until foreclosure. It's complex and uses several variables. Time calculations are tricky, especially with uint256. May lead to errors if not handled properly.

CollectRentUser is a key function. It collects rent and handles foreclosure. The time calculations here are crucial. If the time windows are miscalculated, it could cause incorrect foreclosures or missed rent collections. Also, it uses uint128 for amounts, which is potentially problematic if any function is not handling these properly.

The _increaseMarketBalance function is used in collectRentUser. It's internal, so that's secure. Updates market balance, user deposit, and totalDeposits. But make sure that these changes are atomic and prevent race conditions.

The set...Address functions are all protected by onlyOwner, which is good, except for setOrderbookAddress, it doesn't have a balancedBooks check. Not sure if that's an issue—maybe not, but worth noting.

Overall, the main vulnerabilities I can see are around handling time calculations, especially in RentOwedBetweenTimestmaps and CollectRentUser. Incorrect time calculations could lead to incorrect foreclosures or missed rent payments, leading to loss of funds.

Other possible issues include using uint128 and not properly handling overflows, which could cause unexpected behavior or bugs. Also, the use of SafeCast may not be sufficient if conversion isn't handled correctly.
I also notice that some functions, like updateRentalRate and collectRentUser, have multiple conditions that could lead to logic errors if not carefully tested.

So, I'll flag these areas and suggest careful testing or further review for any off-by-one errors, overflow issues, or incorrect state transitions.","**Vulnerability Analysis and Recommendations for the RCTreasury Smart Contract**
The contract was analyzed for potential vulnerabilities, focusing on key functions and their interactions. Below is a list of identified vulnerabilities along with recommendations for mitigation.

- **Vulnerability**: Functions like `RentOwedBetweenTimestmaps` and `CollectRentUser` perform critical time-based calculations. Errors in these could lead to incorrect rent collection or foreclosure timings.

**Recommendation**: Review all time calculations for accuracy, considering edge cases such as leap years or extreme time values. Use externally verified libraries or functions for timestamp conversions to reduce errors.
- **Vulnerability**: The use of `uint256` in functions like `RentOwedUser` could lead to integer overflow when handling large numbers, causing unexpected behavior or contract failure.
**Recommendation**: Use a third-party library like `OpenZeppelin's SafeMath` to ensure all arithmetic operations are secure against overflows.
- **Vulnerability**: The `_increaseMarketBalance` function and `updateRentalRate` function manipulate state variables without proper locking, potentially leading to race conditions.

**Recommendation**: Implement reentrancy protection or use a lock mechanism to ensure atomicity of state updates. This can be achieved with a reentrancy guard or by wrapping critical operations in a lock.
- **Vulnerability**: Functions like `addMarket` and `changePauseMarket` rely on `isMarket` but do not thoroughly verify user permissions or roles before performing actions.
**Recommendation**: Ensure that all permission checks are robust and are not susceptible to bypass through incorrect role assignments or missing checks.
**5. Potential Front-Running Attacks via Timestamp Manipulation**
- **Vulnerability**: Functions that rely on `block.timestamp` could be vulnerable to front-running attacks if transactions are reordered in the blockchain.
**Recommendation**: Implement a deterministic way to order transactions, or consider reducing dependency on block timestamps where possible. Use off-chain tools or trusted oracles if necessary.
- **Vulnerability**: This function may incorrectly update the `lastRentCalc` and `isForeclosed` flags due to complex time calculations, leading to errors in rent collection or user statuses.

**Recommendation**: Carefully test all pressure points in `CollectRentUser`, including the condition where `rentOwedByUser` exceeds the user's deposit. Consider adding unit tests for edge cases to catch incorrect state transitions.
**7. Potential Mis calculation of Time Intervals**
- **Vulnerability**: Functions that compute intervals (e.g., `RentOwedBetweenTimestmaps`) may miscompute the durations, causing errors in rent collection calculations.
**Recommendation**: Validate the correctness of the time interval calculations. Consider implementing a helper function or using a timer library to ensure accurate timestamp differences.
- **Vulnerability**: The use of `uint128` in functions like `deposit` and `WithdrawDeposit` could lead to overflow issues, especially if not properly checked or converted.
**Recommendation**: Use a math library that handles conversions between different integer types to prevent overflows and ensure accurate arithmetic operations.
- **Vulnerability**: Some functions proceed with state changes without adequately checking preconditions, leading to incorrect behavior or invalid states.
**Recommendation**: Implement detailed pre-checks before making any significant state changes. Use `assert` and `require` statements where possible to catch invalid states early.
- **Vulnerability**: Functions like `WithdrawDeposit` and `PayRent` manipulate critical balances and should not be overridden without thorough testing.

**Recommendation**: Ensure that critical business logic cannot be easily overridden. Consider using sealed or immutable keywords (if available) or restrict function overrides in a way that doesn't allow incorrect behavior.
- **Testing**: Perform comprehensive unit testing, especially focusing on the time-sensitive functions and state transitions.
- **Code Reviews**: Have the contract code reviewed by a team or third party to identify potential logic errors.
- **Libraries**: Use well-reviewed and audited libraries like `OpenZeppelin` for common functionalities to reduce vulnerabilities.
- **Gas Considerations**: Ensure that all operations are efficient to avoid gas-related issues during peak usage.

By addressing these vulnerabilities and implementing the suggested mitigation strategies, the RCTreasury contract can enhance its security and reliability.","### **Analysis of Alignment Between Issue Report and Response List**
#### **[H-01] Unchecked ERC20 Transfers Can Cause Lock Up**

The `topupMarketBalance` function does not handle the return value of ERC20 `transfer` calls. Some ERC20 tokens may return `false` on failure instead of reverting. This could allow malicious actors to call `topupMarketBalance` with a failing transfer, causing `marketBalance` to exceed actual holdings. This would lock up functions like `deposit`, `withdrawDeposit`, `payRent`, `payout`, and `sponsor`, leading to system failure.

The response list does not address this issue. Unchecked ERC20 transfers are a critical vulnerability, and the lack of handling for return values could lead to significant system failures. This is a missed opportunity to recommend using `SafeERC20` or explicitly checking return values.
Recommend using `SafeERC20` from OpenZeppelin to handle ERC20 transfers safely. Additionally, ensure that `topupMarketBalance` checks the return value of the `transfer` call and reverts on failure.
#### **[H-04] Anyone Can Affect Deposits of Any User and Turn the Owner of the Token**

The `collectRentUser` function in `RCTreasury` is public, allowing anyone to call it with arbitrary parameters. This could be exploited to set `isForeclosed[user] = true` for any user by passing `_timeToCollectTo = type(uint256).max`.
This issue is not addressed in the response list. The lack of access control on `collectRentUser` is a significant security flaw, as it allows unauthorized users to manipulate foreclosure states.
Restrict `collectRentUser` to authorized users only. Implement access control using `onlyOwner` or a similar modifier.

The `payout` function in `RCTreasury` does not reset the `isForeclosed` state of a user after a payout. This could lead to incorrect user states, as users who receive funds should no longer be considered foreclosed.
This issue is not addressed in the response list. Failing to reset `isForeclosed` after a payout is a logical error that could lead to incorrect system behavior.
Modify the `payout` function to reset `isForeclosed` for the user after a successful payout.
#### **[M-02] Critical `uberOwner` Address Changes Should Be a Two-Step Process**

The `changeUberOwner` function allows the `uberOwner` to change their address without validation. If an incorrect address is used, the system could be permanently locked, as the `uberOwner` cannot be corrected.
This issue is not addressed in the response list. The lack of a two-step process for critical address changes is a significant security risk.
Implement a two-step process for changing the `uberOwner` address, where the new address must first be proposed and then accepted.
#### **[M-03] Missing `balancedBooks` Modifier Could Result in Failed System Insolvency Detection**
The `balancedBooks` modifier is missing in the `refundUser` and `topupMarketBalance` functions, which could lead to miscalculations and system insolvency.
This issue is not addressed in the response list. The absence of the `balancedBooks` modifier in critical functions is a logical error that could lead to system insolvency.
Apply the `balancedBooks` modifier to `refundUser` and `topupMarketBalance` to ensure proper balance checks.
#### **[M-16] Deposits Can Be Denied by Abusing `maxContractBalance`**
A whale can front-run deposits to push the contract balance to `maxContractBalance`, preventing other users from depositing. This could be exploited to manipulate market outcomes.
This issue is not addressed in the response list. The ability to deny deposits through front-running is a significant vulnerability.
Consider implementing a deposit queue or limiting the maximum deposit amount per user to mitigate this risk.
#### **[M-17] Function `foreclosureTimeUser` Returns a Shorter User's Foreclosure Time Than Expected**
The `foreclosureTimeUser` function underestimates the user's foreclosure time due to incorrect time calculations, leading to potential errors in determining the new owner of the card.
This issue is not addressed in the response list. The incorrect time calculation is a logical error that could lead to incorrect foreclosure decisions.
Review and correct the time calculation logic in `foreclosureTimeUser` to ensure accurate results.

The response identifies potential errors in time-based calculations, such as `RentOwedBetweenTimestmaps` and `CollectRentUser`, and recommends using externally verified libraries for timestamp conversions.
**Valid Concern**. While not explicitly mentioned in the issue report, accurate time calculations are critical for rent collection and foreclosure logic. Using verified libraries is a good practice.
The response highlights the risk of integer overflow in functions like `RentOwedUser` and recommends using OpenZeppelin's `SafeMath`.
**Valid Concern**. While the issue report does not mention integer overflow, it is a common vulnerability in Solidity contracts. Using `SafeMath` is a recommended mitigation.
The response identifies potential race conditions in state updates and recommends implementing reentrancy protection or a lock mechanism.
**Valid Concern**. Race conditions are a significant risk in smart contracts, and the recommendation to use reentrancy guards aligns with best practices.
The response points out insufficient permission checks in functions like `addMarket` and `changePauseMarket` and recommends robust role verification.
**Valid Concern**. Proper permission checks are essential for contract security, and the recommendation to strengthen them is appropriate.
#### **[R-05] Potential Front-Running Attacks via Timestamp Manipulation**
The response identifies front-running risks due to reliance on `block.timestamp` and recommends reducing dependency on timestamps.
**Valid Concern**. Front-running is a well-known issue in blockchain systems, and the recommendation to mitigate it is sound.

/// @notice If you have found a bug, please contact andrew@realitycards.io- no hack pls!!
contract RCMarket is Initializable, NativeMetaTransaction, IRCMarket {
/// @dev so the Factory can check it's a market
bool public constant override isMarket = true
/// @dev counts the total NFTs minted across all events at the time market created
/// @dev keeps track of all the rent paid by each user. So that it can be returned in case of an invalid market outcome.
/// @dev keeps track of all the rent paid for each card, for card specific affiliate payout
/// @dev keeps track of the rent each user has paid for each card, for Safe mode payout
/// @dev an easy way to track the above across all cards
/// @dev prevents user from exiting and re-renting in the same block (limits troll attacks)
/// @dev read from the Factory upon market creation, can not be changed for existing market
/// @dev the minimum required price increase in %
/// @dev minimum rental duration (1 day divisor: i.e. 24 = 1 hour, 48 = 30 mins)
/// @dev maximum number of times to calcualte rent in one transaction
/// @dev how many seconds each user has held each card for, for determining winnings
/// @dev sums all the timeHelds for each. Used when paying out. Should always increment at the same time as timeHeld
/// @dev used to determine the rent due. Rent is due for the period (now - timeLastCollected), at which point timeLastCollected is set to now.
/// @dev to track the max timeheld of each card (for giving NFT to winner)
/// @dev to track who has owned it the most (for giving NFT to winner)
/// @dev to track the card timeHeldLimit for the current owner
/// @dev when the question can be answered on realitio
event LogNewOwner(uint256 indexed cardId, address indexed newOwner)
event LogWinningsPaid(address indexed paidTo, uint256 indexed amountPaid)
event LogSponsor(address indexed sponsor, uint256 indexed amount)
/// @param _mode 0 = normal, 1 = winner takes all, 2 = Safe Mode
/// @param _timestamps for market opening, locking, and oracle resolution
/// @param _numberOfCards how many Cards in this market
/// @param _totalNftMintCount total existing Cards across all markets excl this event's Cards
/// @param _artistAddress where to send artist's cut, if any
/// @param _affiliateAddress where to send affiliate's cut, if any
/// @param _cardAffiliateAddresses where to send card specific affiliate's cut, if any
/// @param _marketCreatorAddress where to send market creator's cut, if any
/// @param _realitioQuestion the question posted to the Oracle
// get adjustable parameters from the factory/treasury
// reduce artist cut to zero if zero adddress set
// reduce affiliate cut to zero if zero adddress set
// check the validity of card affiliate array.
// if not valid, reduce payout to zero
// if winner takes all mode, set winnerCut to max
// move to OPEN immediately if market opening time in the past
/// @dev can only be called by Card owners
/// @dev upgrades not possible if market not approved
/// @notice gets the owner of the NFT via their Card Id
function ownerOf(uint256 _cardId) public view override returns (address) {
/// @notice gets tokenURI via their Card Id
/// @dev called internally during contract open state
/// @dev called externaly by Orderbook during contract open state
/// @dev market.setWinner() will revert if done twice, because wrong state
// check market state to prevent market closing early
/// @notice checks whether the competition has ended, if so moves to LOCKED state
/// @dev public because called within autoLock modifier & setWinner
// do a final rent collection before the contract is locked down
// bring the cards back to the market so the winners get the satisfcation of claiming them
/// @notice called by getWinnerFromOracle, sets the winner
/// @param _winningOutcome the index of the winning card
// change the locking time to allow lockMarket to lock
// get the winner. This will revert if answer is not resolved.
/// @notice pays out winnings, or returns funds
/// @notice the longest owner of each NFT gets to keep it
/// @dev LOCKED or WITHDRAW states are fine- does not need to wait for winner to be known
/// @param _card the id of the card, the index
// calculate longest owner's extra winnings, if relevant
// return all rent paid on winning card
/// @notice returns all funds to users in case of invalid outcome
// deduct artist share and card specific share if relevant but NOT market creator share or winner's share (no winner, market creator does not deserve)
/// @dev the below functions pay stakeholders (artist, creator, affiliate, card specific affiliates)
/// @dev they are not called within setWinner() because of the risk of an
/// @dev ....  address being a contract which refuses payment, then nobody could get winnings
/// @dev [hangover from when ether was native currency, keeping in case we return to this]
/// @dev does not call _processStakeholderPayment because it works differently
/// @dev basically functions that have _checkState(States.OPEN) on first line
/// @dev cannot be external because it is called within the lockMarket function, therefore public
/// @notice rent every Card at the minimum price
/// @param _maxSumOfPrices a limit to the sum of the bids to place
// check that not being front run
/// @dev no event: it is emitted in _updateBid, _setNewOwner or _placeInList as appropriate
/// @param _newPrice the price to rent the card for
/// @param _timeHeldLimit an optional time limit to rent the card for
/// @param _startingPosition where to start looking to insert the bid into the orderbook

}",5732.0,635.0,"[M-05] RCFactory.createMarket() does not enforce _timestamps and _timestamps being larger than _timestamps, even though proper functioning requires them to be so
`RCFactory.createMarket()` does not enforce `_timestamps[1]` and `_timestamps[2]` being larger than _timestamps[0], even though proper functioning requires them to be so.
IRCMarket defines a sequence of events that each market should progress through sequentially, CLOSED, OPEN, LOCKED, WITHDRAW. (1)
The comments explicitly state that _incrementState() should be called ""thrice"" (2)
However, it is possible to create a market where these events do not occur sequentially.
You can create a market where the marketOpeningTime is later than the marketLockingTime and oracleResolutionTime.
This is because although RCFactory checks to ensure that _timestamps[2] is greater than _timestamps[1], it does not check to ensure that _timestamps[1] is greater than _timestamps[0] (3)

This is also because although RCFactory checks to ensure that _timestamps[0] is equal to or greater than block.timestamp, it makes no check for a minimum value for _timestamps[1] or _timestamps[2], or a relative check between the value of _timestamps[0] and _timestamps[1]. (4)
Thus, you can create a market where the marketLockingTime and the oracleResolutionTime occur before the marketOpeningTime.

When calling RCFactory.createMarket(), Alice can supply 0 as the argument for _timestamps[1] and _timestamps[2], and any value equal to or greater than block.timestamp for _timestamps[0] (5)",1.0,"pragma solidity 0.8.4

1. **Reentrancy Risk**: The contract does not employ reentrancy protection, which could expose it to attacks where an attacker repeatedly calls external functions until a revert occurs, potentially leading to unauthorized state changes or financial loss.

2. **Inadequate Market Creation Approval Controls**: The `createMarket` function allows certain users to bypass approval checks if specific flags (`marketCreationGovernorsOnly`, `approvedArtistsOnly`, `approvedAffilliatesOnly`) are set to false or manipulated. This could lead to the creation of unapproved or malicious markets.

3. **Unrestricted Market Address Handling**: The `getMostRecentMarket` and `getAllMarkets` functions use `_mode` as an index without sufficiently validating it. This could lead to unintended or erroneous market data retrieval if the `_mode` value is improperly utilized elsewhere.

4. **Dependence on External Contracts**: The trie of functions including `treasury.checkSponsorship` and interactions with `IRCMarket`, `nfthub`, and `orderbook` could introduce vulnerabilities if these external contracts themselves have issues with security or reentrancy, as does the `NativeMetaTransaction`.

5. **Potential Manipulation of Reference Contract Versioning**: The `referenceContractVersion` is incremented each time a new market is created. Without a cap, this could lead to excessively large version numbers, potentially causing issues with other compatible contracts that rely on this versioning.

6. **Unrestricted Governor Approval Changes**: The `changeMarketApproval`, `changeArtistApproval`, and `changeAffiliateApproval` functions allow governors to modify approval statuses. If governors are not sufficiently authenticated or secured, this could lead to unintended market or approval changes.

These vulnerabilities, while present, were identified without requiring mitigation as per the problem constraints.","### **[M-05] RCFactory.createMarket() does not enforce _timestamps[1] and _timestamps[2] being larger than _timestamps[0]**

The `RCFactory.createMarket()` function does not enforce that `_timestamps[1]` and `_timestamps[2]` are larger than `_timestamps[0]`, even though proper functioning requires them to be so. The `IRCMarket` defines a sequence of events (CLOSED, OPEN, LOCKED, WITHDRAW) that each market should progress through sequentially. However, it is possible to create a market where these events do not occur sequentially. Specifically, `_timestamps[1]` (marketLockingTime) and `_timestamps[2]` (oracleResolutionTime) can be set to values less than `_timestamps[0]` (marketOpeningTime). This is because `RCFactory` only checks that `_timestamps[2]` is greater than `_timestamps[1]` but does not validate the relationship between `_timestamps[0]` and `_timestamps[1]`. Additionally, while `_timestamps[0]` is checked to be equal to or greater than `block.timestamp`, there are no minimum value checks for `_timestamps[1]` or `_timestamps[2]`. This oversight allows for the creation of markets with illogical or invalid timestamps, which could disrupt the intended functionality of the contract.

The issue is **completely unaddressed** in the `response_list`. The response list does not mention or provide any mitigation for the improper validation of timestamps in the `createMarket` function. This is a significant oversight, as it directly impacts the logical correctness and security of the contract.
